verses.text: But the children of Israel did evil in the sight of the LORD. So the LORD gave them into the hand of Midian for seven years.
verses.comment: Preserves the sense that Israel's trouble is a result of their disobedience.

verses.text: The hand of Midian prevailed against Israel. Because of Midian, the children of Israel made themselves the dens which are in the mountains, and the caves, and the strongholds.
verses.comment: Simple list of shelter types reflects Hebrew.

verses.text: Whenever Israel had sown, Midianites, Amalekites, and the people of the east would come up against them.
verses.comment: Maintains list of invading groups.

verses.text: They camped against them and destroyed the produce of the land as far as Gaza. They left no sustenance in Israel, nor sheep, nor ox, nor donkey.
verses.comment: ‘Sustenance’ is a literal rendering of food provision.

verses.text: They came up with their livestock and their tents; they came in like locusts for number. Both they and their camels were innumerable; and they entered the land to destroy it.
verses.comment: ‘Locusts for number’ is word-for-word.

verses.text: Israel was brought very low because of Midian, and the children of Israel cried out to the LORD.
verses.comment: ‘Brought very low’ as literal as possible.

verses.text: When the children of Israel cried out to the LORD because of Midian,
verses.comment: Sets up the prophet’s message.

verses.text: the LORD sent a prophet to the children of Israel. He said to them, “This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: ‘I brought you up from Egypt, and brought you out of the house of bondage;
verses.comment: Direct speech preserved.

verses.text: I delivered you out of the hand of the Egyptians and out of the hand of all who oppressed you, and drove them out from before you and gave you their land.’
verses.comment: Chronological retelling of history.

verses.text: I said to you, ‘I am the LORD your God; do not fear the gods of the Amorites, in whose land you dwell.’ But you did not obey my voice.
verses.comment: ‘Fear’ as in ‘revere’ or ‘worship’—literal sense kept.

verses.text: Then the angel of the LORD came and sat under the oak that was in Ophrah, which belonged to Joash the Abiezrite. His son Gideon was threshing wheat in the winepress to hide it from the Midianites.
verses.comment: ‘Winepress’ and ‘oak’ are literal translation.

verses.text: The angel of the LORD appeared to him and said to him, “The LORD is with you, mighty man of valor!”
verses.comment: ‘Mighty man of valor’ maintains the Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: Gideon said to him, “O my lord, if the LORD is with us, why then has all this happened to us? And where are all His wonders which our fathers told us about, saying, ‘Did not the LORD bring us up from Egypt?’ But now the LORD has abandoned us and given us into the hand of Midian.”
verses.comment: Gideon's lament is translated as close as possible.

verses.text: The LORD turned to him and said, “Go in this your strength and save Israel from the hand of Midian. Have I not sent you?”
verses.comment: God’s call rendered literally; God ‘turns’ may be metaphorical for attention.

verses.text: Gideon said to Him, “O Lord, how can I save Israel? My clan is the weakest in Manasseh, and I am the least in my father’s house.”
verses.comment: ‘Least’ and ‘weakest’ retain original word choice.

verses.text: The LORD said to him, “Surely I will be with you, and you shall strike the Midianites as one man.”
verses.comment: ‘As one man’ reflects Hebrew idiom for unity.

verses.text: He said to Him, “If now I have found favor in Your eyes, then show me a sign that it is You who speak with me.”
verses.comment: Request for a sign rendered literally.

verses.text: Please do not depart from here until I come to You and bring My offering and set it before You.” And He said, “I will wait until you return.”
verses.comment: ‘Offering’, ‘wait’, and ‘return’ are direct.

verses.text: So Gideon went in and prepared a young goat and unleavened bread from an ephah of flour. He put the meat in a basket and the broth in a pot, and brought them out to Him under the oak and presented them.
verses.comment: Details of the preparation matched to Hebrew.

verses.text: The angel of God said to him, “Take the meat and the unleavened bread and lay them on this rock, and pour out the broth.” And he did so.
verses.comment: ‘Lay them on this rock’—language as literal as possible.

verses.text: Then the angel of the LORD reached out the end of the staff that was in his hand and touched the meat and the unleavened bread. Fire rose from the rock and consumed the meat and the unleavened bread. Then the angel of the LORD vanished from his sight.
verses.comment: ‘Rose from the rock’—miraculous manifestation.

verses.text: When Gideon realized that he was the angel of the LORD, he said, “Alas, O Lord GOD! For I have seen the angel of the LORD face to face!”
verses.comment: ‘Face to face’ is a theological idiom retained.

verses.text: But the LORD said to him, “Peace to you. Do not fear; you shall not die.”
verses.comment: Concise reassurance, word-for-word.

verses.text: Then Gideon built an altar there to the LORD and named it “The LORD is Peace.” To this day it stands at Ophrah of the Abiezrites.
verses.comment: ‘The LORD is Peace’ translates Yahweh-Shalom.

verses.text: That night the LORD said to him, “Take your father’s bull, and the second bull seven years old, and pull down the altar of Baal that your father has, and cut down the Asherah that is beside it.
verses.comment: ‘Asherah’ is left as a transliteration of the idol.

verses.text: Build an altar to the LORD your God on top of this stronghold, in the proper arrangement. Take the second bull and offer it as a burnt offering with the wood of the Asherah which you shall cut down.”
verses.comment: ‘In the proper arrangement’ is literal for ‘orderly way’.

verses.text: So Gideon took ten men from among his servants and did as the LORD had told him. But because he feared his father’s household and the men of the city, he did it by night.
verses.comment: ‘He did it by night’ preserves the original detail.

verses.text: When the men of the city arose early in the morning, behold, the altar of Baal was broken down and the Asherah beside it was cut down, and the second bull was offered on the altar that had been built.
verses.comment: Details of destruction rendered directly.

verses.text: They said to one another, “Who has done this thing?” And when they investigated and asked, they said, “Gideon the son of Joash has done this thing.”
verses.comment: Dialogue captured as rendered.

verses.text: Then the men of the city said to Joash, “Bring out your son, so that he may die, because he has broken down the altar of Baal and cut down the Asherah beside it.”
verses.comment: ‘Bring out your son, so that he may die’ literal.

verses.text: But Joash said to all who stood against him, “Will you contend for Baal, or will you save him? Whoever contends for him shall be put to death by morning. If he is a god, let him contend for himself because his altar has been broken down.”
verses.comment: Joash’s challenge rendered directly, possible sarcasm preserved.

verses.text: Therefore, on that day he was called Jerubbaal, saying, “Let Baal contend against him, because he broke down his altar.”
verses.comment: ‘Jerubbaal’ meaning reflected.

verses.text: Then all the Midianites, the Amalekites, and the people of the east gathered together, crossed over, and camped in the Valley of Jezreel.
verses.comment: ‘Valley of Jezreel’ rendered as literal place.

verses.text: But the Spirit of the LORD clothed Gideon, and he blew the trumpet, and the Abiezrites gathered behind him.
verses.comment: ‘Clothed’ as a Hebrew idiom for empowerment.

verses.text: He sent messengers throughout all Manasseh, who also gathered behind him. He also sent messengers to Asher, Zebulun, and Naphtali, and they came up to meet them.
verses.comment: Names retained; ‘came up’ is literal movement language.

verses.text: Gideon said to God, “If You will save Israel by my hand, as You have said—
verses.comment: Conditional if-statement rendered directly.

verses.text: look, I am placing a fleece of wool on the threshing floor. If there is dew on the fleece alone and it is dry on all the ground, then I will know that You will save Israel by my hand, as You have said.”
verses.comment: ‘Fleece’ kept as the specific object.

verses.text: And so it was. When he arose early the next morning and squeezed the fleece, he wrung enough dew from the fleece to fill a bowl with water.
verses.comment: ‘Wringing dew’ direct to Hebrew.

verses.text: Then Gideon said to God, “Let not Your anger be hot against me, and I will speak only once more. Please let me test just one more time with the fleece: let it be dry only on the fleece, and on all the ground let there be dew.”
verses.comment: ‘Let not Your anger be hot’ preserves Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: And God did so that night: it was dry only on the fleece, and there was dew on all the ground.
verses.comment: Miracle described plainly and literally.
